action.content:
Q: Is the following sentence plausible? "Ryan Nugent-Hopkins killed the powerplay."
A: no, in hockey, "killing the powerplay" is not a standard term; a more likely term would be "killing the play" or "killing the game" in a different context, but in hockey, it's more likely that a team would "kill a powerplay" by successfully defending against a man advantage, rather than "killing" it.
Q: Is the following sentence plausible? "Nikita Kucherov made a game-saving block in the third period of the Stanley Cup Finals."
A: yes
Q: Is the following sentence plausible? "Patrik Laine won the faceoff in the neutral zone of the game against the Toronto Maple Leafs."
A: yes
Q: Is the following sentence plausible? "Erik Karlsson made a game-tying goal in the third period of the Stanley Cup Playoffs."
A: yes
Q: Is the following sentence plausible? "Sergei Bobrovsky made a game-tying goal in the third period of the Stanley Cup Playoffs."
A: no, in hockey, goalies (goalkeepers) do not score goals; they play in the net and try to prevent goals from being scored.
Q: Is the following sentence plausible? "Nikita Kucherov made a game-tying goal in the third period of the Stanley Cup Playoffs."
